notes: Writing styles are applied at section-level. Use global rules for all outputs, then add style rules for the selected style. Recommended style set updated to 9 styles (adds Operational Reporting, renames Narrative Insight -> Strategic Narrative, broadens Technical Architecture -> Technical & Systems Design).
global_enforced_rules: Do not hallucinate facts, data, metrics, regulatory positions, dates, or sources.
If information is missing or uncertain, clearly state assumptions and label uncertainty explicitly.
Maintain internal consistency across sections (numbers, dates, entities, conclusions).
Avoid contradictory statements. If trade-offs exist, articulate them explicitly.
Use professional, business-appropriate language. Avoid slang, memes, and overly casual phrasing.
Do not fabricate legal, compliance, financial, or contractual claims.
Do not include confidential data unless it is explicitly provided in the input context.

writing_styles.name: Executive Briefing
writing_styles.description: Concise, decision-oriented summary for senior stakeholders; emphasizes key findings, implications, and actions.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in an executive briefing style. Be concise, outcome-focused, and insight-driven. Use short paragraphs and bullet points. Prioritize key findings, implications, and decisions over background detail. Assume a time-constrained senior audience.
enforced_rules: Start with key outcomes and decision-relevant highlights.
Use bullets wherever possible; keep paragraphs short (2–4 lines).
Explicitly state implications and recommended next actions.
Avoid deep technical methodology unless it materially changes decisions.
Prefer concrete numbers and dates; if unavailable, state what is missing.

writing_styles.name: Analytical Research
writing_styles.description: Objective, evidence-based analysis with logical structure, comparisons, assumptions, and limitations.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in an analytical research style. Structure the response logically with clear sections, use evidence-based reasoning, compare alternatives where relevant, highlight assumptions and limitations, and maintain an objective, data-driven tone. Prefer structured analysis over narrative prose.
enforced_rules: Separate facts from interpretations; label opinions as hypotheses.
Support major claims with reasoning or data; state gaps explicitly.
Include assumptions and limitations in each relevant section.
Use comparative analysis (peers, benchmarks, trends) when relevant.
Avoid persuasive/marketing language; keep tone neutral.

writing_styles.name: Strategic Narrative
writing_styles.description: Context-first strategic explanation connecting drivers, positioning, and future outlook in a coherent storyline.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in a strategic narrative style. Provide clear context, explain the 'why' behind events and trends, connect sections into a coherent strategic story, and end with implications for direction and priorities. Keep it professional and executive-appropriate, not blog-like.
enforced_rules: Open with context and strategic drivers before details.
Connect cause → effect → implication explicitly.
Avoid casual storytelling; keep a professional, business tone.
Do not introduce unsupported claims; ground narrative in stated facts.
End with strategic implications, priorities, or options.

writing_styles.name: Structured Specification
writing_styles.description: Precise, unambiguous, implementation-ready requirements and statements; best for BRDs and test artifacts.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in a structured specification style. Use precise, unambiguous language. Organize content into clearly numbered sections, subsections, and bullet points. Avoid narrative or marketing language. Every requirement should be atomic, testable, and implementation-ready.
enforced_rules: Use numbered sections/subsections; keep hierarchy consistent.
Each requirement must be atomic, testable, and uniquely identifiable (e.g., FR-001).
Use SHALL / SHOULD / MAY consistently to indicate obligation level.
Avoid subjective language (e.g., 'easy', 'robust') without measurable criteria.
Include validations, error handling, and edge cases where relevant.

writing_styles.name: Solution Proposal
writing_styles.description: Customer-centric proposal mapping requirements to capabilities; balances clarity with persuasive value framing.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in a solution proposal style. Address the customer's needs directly, map requirements to proposed capabilities, explain how the solution works, and highlight value, differentiation, and feasibility. Balance clarity with persuasive framing.
enforced_rules: Map requirements to capabilities explicitly (e.g., requirement → approach → outcome).
Clearly distinguish current capabilities vs roadmap items.
State assumptions, dependencies, and customer responsibilities explicitly.
Avoid unsubstantiated promises; qualify where necessary.
Include delivery approach (timeline, milestones) when relevant.

writing_styles.name: Technical & Systems Design
writing_styles.description: System-level design covering components, data flows, integrations, scalability, performance, and security.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in a technical & systems design style. Focus on system components, responsibilities, data flows, integrations, scalability, performance, security, and operational considerations. Use structured lists and diagrams-in-text where helpful. Avoid business fluff.
enforced_rules: Describe components and responsibilities explicitly (who does what).
Explain key data flows and integration points clearly.
Address security, reliability, observability, and performance considerations.
Use technical terminology consistently; avoid marketing language.
Include failure modes and mitigations where important.

writing_styles.name: Compliance & Risk-Oriented
writing_styles.description: Formal, conservative style emphasizing controls, governance, auditability, risks, and mitigations.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in a compliance and risk-oriented style. Emphasize controls, validations, governance, auditability, and regulatory alignment. Clearly identify risks, mitigations, assumptions, and exclusions. Use formal, conservative language.
enforced_rules: Explicitly list risks and mitigations; include residual risk where relevant.
Avoid absolute guarantees; use qualified language appropriately.
State regulatory assumptions and scope exclusions explicitly.
Describe controls, approvals, audit trails, and monitoring expectations.
Prefer verifiable statements over opinions.

writing_styles.name: Instructional Playbook
writing_styles.description: Step-by-step, repeatable operational guidance using checklists, decision rules, and examples.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in an instructional playbook style. Provide step-by-step guidance, clear actions, decision rules, and examples. Use numbered steps, checklists, and do/don't guidance. Optimize for repeatable execution.
enforced_rules: Use numbered steps for procedures; include prerequisites and inputs.
Include decision rules and checkpoints (if/then) where relevant.
Provide checklists for repeatable execution.
Include do/don't guidance and common pitfalls.
Avoid theory-heavy explanations unless necessary for correct execution.

writing_styles.name: Operational Reporting
writing_styles.description: Factual, metric-led reporting focused on KPIs, trends, variances, drivers, and actions.
writing_styles.llm_instruction: Write in an operational reporting style. Focus on factual performance reporting using metrics, trends, variances, and drivers. Use tables/bullets for KPIs, clearly distinguish actuals vs targets, and end with operational actions and owners when applicable. Keep the tone neutral and execution-focused.
enforced_rules: Prioritize metrics and trends; include period, baseline, and comparison where possible.
Clearly distinguish actuals vs targets vs prior period; if missing, state what is unavailable.
Explain key drivers for variances (what changed and why).
Keep tone neutral and factual; avoid speculation.
End with recommended operational actions, owners/roles, and timelines when applicable.
